thread.title: Central Catholic graduate Noah Robb will play a key role for Lehigh defense
thread.title_full: Central Catholic graduate Noah Robb will play a key role for Lehigh defense - The Morning Call

author: Keith Groller
title: Central Catholic graduate Noah Robb will play a key role for Lehigh defense
text:
Noah Robb won a state title as a junior at Central Catholic in 2010, a memory that stays fresh in his mind.
"Sometimes I'll dream about it and sometimes the dream doesn't go as well â€¦ and I actually mess up on the last play or something," Robb said smiling. "It's nice that I'll always have that to look back on and cherish."
But Robb would like to have one more championship moment to take from his football career and that's to celebrate a Patriot League title at Lehigh.
Robb, a senior linebacker for the Mountain Hawks, has one last chance to get his championship ring and if it's going to happen, it has to start with a win over defending league champion Fordham on Saturday at Jack Coffey Stadium in the Bronx.
The Rams (6-1, 2-0 Patriot) are ranked No. 10 in the nation by one poll, No. 11 by another and feature the No. 1 ranked in the league and No. 14 in the country at 468 yards per game.
If Lehigh (3-3, 1-0) is going to pull an upset it's going to be Robb and the defense at the forefront of the surprise.
"We're excited, especially coming off the bye week when we had an extra week to prepare," Robb said. "We're itching to hit someone in a different uniform because it's been a pretty physical bye week."
Robb said members of the defense have to worry about doing their own jobs and stay "assignment-sound."
The focus will be on trying to contain the Rams' remarkable running back, sophomore Chase Edmonds, who is No. 1 in the country in scoring (16.3 ppg) and No. 3 nationally in rushing (149.4 ypg)
"He's the real deal," Robb said.
Lehigh coach Andy Coen said the offense must do its part to not only score points, but not give the ball away.
Fordham lost to Villanova on Sept. 12 and has had some close calls with several other teams, including a 48-45 win over Penn two weeks ago and a 47-41 overtime triumph over Holy Cross last week.
"They have been giving up some points, more than they did last year," Coen said. "But the big thing is that we have to stay balanced on offense and not turn it over. Penn got down 21-0 to them because of turnovers and they were able to chip away, but it wasn't enough. We have a chance to score some points. Will it be enough?"
Last year as a freshman, Edmonds, a Central Dauphin East product, had 1,838 yards (the fourth most in a Patriot League season) and scored 23 touchdowns (tied for second-best in league history). Included in that breakout season was a 197-yard effort against Lehigh.
This year, Edmonds has 1,046 yards rushing, an average of 6.7 yards per carry and 149.4 per game.
"The defense has to continue to do what it did in the second half of the Yale game and at Bucknell," Coen said. "At Bucknell, we had a good pass rush the whole game and it was the most passionate I've seen our team play.
"We were really plugged in and excited to play. Even after we gave up a scoring drive on the first possession of the game, we came back and didn't really give up anything the rest of the way even when the offense made some mistakes."
Lehigh is ranked sixth out of the seven Patriot League team in defense, allowing 434.8 yards per game, including 190.7 on the ground.
Robb said the defense is definitely improved from 2014, but isn't where it wants to be yet.
"We've still got a lot of work to do and we're still working hard on getting better every single time we step on the field," Robb said. "We've made a lot of progress, even from two weeks ago. We're getting there."
And, certainly Robb is right where he needs to be as a key cog in the defense from his outside linebacker spot. He has been moved around position-wise throughout his Lehigh career, but has found a home and is making the most of it with 34 tackles, the third most on the team. He had seven tackles, including a sack, at Bucknell.
"Noah was our defensive player of the week last week and he keeps playing really well," Coen said. "We've found a good fit for him with the scheme we're in.
"We thought he would be a good inside linebacker for us, but he never gained the weight we thought he would, but he's in a good spot for us now. He has to do a lot of pass coverage for us and he's athletic enough to be able to do that, but he's also very physical. I'm happy for him after what he went through and I'm happy he's playing so well as a senior."
Robb, listed at 6-foot-3 and 215 pounds, will be happy if Lehigh can finish this season strong.
"It was one of the best decisions I've ever made to come here," Robb said of staying in the Lehigh Valley. "I like being close to home but I only go home on the weekends to have my mom do my laundry. I've received a great education and couldn't ask for a better place to spend the best four years of my life. But I don't want to leave Lehigh without a [championship] ring."
